results.title: Rabbit control. Part 3: working in groups
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Conservation and Environment, Ian Blythman and Barbara "Tess" Dullard
results.brief_description: Part 3 of a program designed to control the rabbit populations and their adverse effects on farming. This episode narrated by Maurie Fields suggests a solution to the problem - working in groups. By forming a local “Rabbit Control Group” or “Land Care Group” farmers would be able to: 1-reduce their costs by having proper equipment and supplies available when needed, 2-have effective rabbit control on all properties, and 3-moral and motivation would be boosted via the social contact between all members of the community. The local C.F.and L. office would also assist with information for the natural regeneration of trees and grasses. Effective rabbit control would benefit the environment by ensuring the return of the natural wildlife and also increase agricultural productivity.

results.title: Rabbit control. Part 2: follow up
results.creator_credit: Dept of Conservation, Forests and Land, John Atkins and Ian Blythman
results.brief_description: Part 2 of a programme designed to control the rabbit population and their adverse effects on farming. This episode, which is narrated by Maurie Fields, looks at fumigation, destruction of habitat, baiting and shooting with follow-up procedures to ensure successful control of rabbit populations.

results.title: Rabbit-Proof Fence
results.creator_credit: Film Finance Corporation Australia, Premium Movie Partnership, South Australian Film Corporation, Jabel Films, Phil Noyce and Christine Olsen
results.brief_description: ‘Rabbit-Proof Fence’ is based on the true story of three Aboriginal girls, Molly, Daisy and Gracie, who in 1931 were forcibly removed from their mothers and home in Jigalong, Western Australia, and sent to a settlement 2000 kilometres away to be trained as domestic servants and inducted into White culture. Upon arrival, the girls are instantly averse to their strange, rather grotesque new world, and decide to take matters into their own hands by attempting an escape and return home. Here begins the girls’ seemingly eternal, epic journey across the harsh Australian desert landscape, with all odds against them except for a rabbit-proof fence as their guide home. In a moving finale, they are reunited with their mothers and, significantly, their culture. Though it is a specifically Australian story (the Stolen Generations and the White Australia Policy), director Phillip Noyce tells it in such a way that emphasises universal qualities of tragedy and heroism. He opts for an even-handed portrayal of the past, steering clear of images of oppression or subjugation and any chastising of White Culture, and instead emphasises optimism and survival. The film is adapted from a book of the same title by author, Doris Pilkington, daughter of the real-life Molly and ‘Stolen Generation’ victim. Christopher Doyle’s photography and Peter Gabriel’s score give spiritual resonance to moments of emotional intensity, such as the tearing of children from their mothers, the crossing of a daunting barren landscape and the homecoming embrace between mother and daughter. Stars Everlyn Sampi, Tianna Sansbury, Laura Monaghan, Kenneth Branagh, David Gupilil, Deborah Mailman. Also includes the 35-minute documentary “Following the Rabbit Proof Fence” by Darlene Johnson.

holdings.name: MOV file H264; NFSA Digital Access Copy

results.title: Raak
results.brief_description: The life story of the wedge-tailed eagle. Raak was born on the edge of the desert and spent his early years learning to hunt and kill. In his seventh year he went south to find a mate, built a nest in the mountains, where they raised two broods of eaglets. The eaglets are shown growing up, learning to fly and eventually leaving the nest. Photographed and recorded by Peter Bruce and David Corke. Narrated by Ian Neil.

results.title: RAAF Record. Newsreel No. 12
results.creator_credit: Australia. Royal Australian Air Force. Directorate of Public Relations
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine newsreel includes the following: 1. In response to a SEATO request for assistance in Thailand, the 79th Squadron RAAF was based in South-eastern Thailand. Hercules transports flew in all ground personnel and equipment so that the base could be in working order immediately for the Sabre Jets which are equipped with air missiles. 2. Freedom of the city of Wagga was given to members of the RAAF in impressive ceremonies at the air base and in the city of Wagga.

results.title: RAAF Record. Newsreel No. 08
results.creator_credit: Australia. Royal Australian Air Force. Directorate of Public Relations, Stanley Brogden and L.H. Hicks
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine newsreel includes the following: 1. RAAF’s Lockheed Hercules transport. 2. Supersonic “dart” is practice target for fighters. 3. “Sarah” (search and rescue and homing) is a new radio device for sea rescues. 4. The RAAF Antarctic flight visits the Soviet base.

results.title: RAAF Record. Newsreel No. 07
results.creator_credit: Australia. Royal Australian Air Force. Directorate of Public Relations and Stanley Brogden
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine newsreel includes the following: 1. The RAAF flight in the Antarctic use Canadian “Beaver” aircraft. 2. RAAF personnel are trained by firemen in Melbourne. 3. The Lockheed Hercules transport. 4. The “Jindivik” pilotless aircraft, designed and built in Australia, shown in flight at Woomera range.
